title: Psalms Chapter 12 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 12 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 12 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 12.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalms 12 according to the chapter text?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:1 states that it is a Psalm of David.

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask the LORD to help with in Psalms 12:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Because the godly man ceaseth
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:1 says, 'Help, LORD; for the godly man ceaseth.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 12:2, how do people speak to their neighbors?
questions.correctAnswer: With vanity and flattering lips
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:2 states they speak vanity and with flattering lips and a double heart.

questions.question: What will the LORD do to flattering lips according to Psalms 12:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Cut them off
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:3 says the LORD shall cut off all flattering lips.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'With our tongue will we ______; our lips are our own.'
questions.correctAnswer: prevail
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:4 says, 'With our tongue will we prevail; our lips are our own.'

questions.question: Who will the LORD arise for, according to Psalms 12:5?
questions.correctAnswer: The poor and needy
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:5 states the LORD will arise for the oppression of the poor and the sighing of the needy.

questions.question: According to Psalms 12:6, how are the words of the LORD described?
options: Pure as silver tried in a furnace
questions.correctAnswer: Pure as silver tried in a furnace
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:6 describes the words of the LORD as pure words, like silver tried in a furnace.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 12:7 says the LORD will preserve His words forever.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:7 states the LORD shall preserve them from this generation forever.

questions.question: What do the wicked do according to Psalms 12:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Walk on every side
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:8 says the wicked walk on every side.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 12:4 questions who has lordship over their lips.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:4 says, 'Who is lord over us?' referring to their lips.

questions.question: According to Psalms 12:5, the LORD will set the needy in safety from whom?
questions.correctAnswer: Him that puffeth at him
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:5 states the LORD will set the needy in safety from him that puffeth at him.

questions.question: What do the people speak with, as mentioned in Psalms 12:2?
options: Flattering lips and a double heart
questions.correctAnswer: Flattering lips and a double heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:2 says they speak with flattering lips and a double heart.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 12:3 states the LORD will bless proud tongues.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:3 says the LORD shall cut off the tongue that speaketh proud things.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'As silver tried in a furnace of ______, purified seven times.'
questions.correctAnswer: earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:6 uses the phrase 'as silver tried in a furnace of earth.'

questions.question: Who are exalted according to Psalms 12:8?
questions.correctAnswer: The vilest men
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:8 states that the vilest men are exalted.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 12 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 12 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with discouragement because the faithful seem to be failing around them. Based on Psalms 12, what biblical truth would you share about God’s care for the faithful?
options: God will preserve the faithful forever
The faithful must rely only on themselves
Faithful people will never face trials
questions.correctAnswer: God will preserve the faithful forever
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:7 assures that God will preserve the faithful from this generation forever, offering hope and encouragement to those feeling abandoned.

questions.question: How does Psalms 12 teach us about integrity in speech when dealing with others?
options: We should avoid flattery and double-hearted speech
Flattering speech is a wise way to gain favor
Silence is the best way to handle communication
questions.correctAnswer: We should avoid flattery and double-hearted speech
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:2 warns against speaking with flattering lips and double hearts, highlighting the importance of honest and sincere communication.

questions.question: If someone is tempted to claim independence over their words and actions, what correction does Psalms 12 offer?
options: The LORD is Lord over all, including our words
Everyone has full control over their speech
Lips belong to the individual alone
Speech is free from any accountability
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is Lord over all, including our words
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:4 challenges the idea that lips and tongues belong to individuals alone by reminding us that God is Lord over all speech and behavior.

questions.question: How does this passage encourage believers to respond to oppression and suffering of the needy?
options: God will arise to save the oppressed
Only human effort can deliver the needy
Sighing of the needy is unnoticed by God
questions.correctAnswer: God will arise to save the oppressed
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:5 expresses that God hears the sighs of the needy and will rise to protect them from their oppressors, encouraging trust in God's justice.

questions.question: What does Psalms 12 teach about the purity and reliability of God's words?
options: God’s words are pure, like silver refined seven times
God’s words are uncertain and changeable
Human words are purer than God’s
God’s words are hidden and unclear
questions.correctAnswer: God’s words are pure, like silver refined seven times
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:6 describes God’s words as pure and refined like silver purified seven times, affirming their trustworthiness and perfection.

questions.question: A believer feels surrounded by wickedness and pride. Based on Psalms 12, what biblical perspective should they adopt?
options: Wickedness is prevalent but God preserves the faithful
Evil will not increase, so no concern is needed
questions.correctAnswer: Wickedness is prevalent but God preserves the faithful
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:8 notes the prevalence of wickedness and pride, but verses 7 and 6 remind believers that God’s preservation and pure word remain a sure foundation.

questions.question: How does Psalms 12 guide us in trusting God during times when godly people seem to fail?
options: Trust that God will preserve the faithful despite appearances
Give up faith because the godly have ceased
Assume God has abandoned His people
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God will preserve the faithful despite appearances
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:1 and 12:7 together encourage believers to call on God and trust His preservation, even when faithful people seem to fail around them.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 12, God will cut off all flattering lips and proud tongues.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:3 clearly states that the LORD shall cut off flattering lips and tongues that speak proud things, indicating God's judgment on deceitful speech.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD ignores the sighing of the needy according to Psalms 12.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:5 affirms that God hears the oppression of the poor and sighing of the needy and will arise to protect them.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "The words of the LORD are pure words: as ______ tried in a furnace of earth, purified seven times."
questions.correctAnswer: silver
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:6 uses the analogy of silver refined seven times to describe the purity of God's words, emphasizing their perfect reliability.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to speak with flattering lips to gain favor. Based on Psalms 12, what should they remember about such speech?
options: Flattering lips will be cut off by the LORD
Flattery is an effective and approved method
questions.correctAnswer: Flattering lips will be cut off by the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:3 warns that the LORD will cut off all flattering lips, teaching us to avoid insincere speech and pursue honesty.

questions.question: How does Psalms 12 teach us about God's role in protecting the oppressed and needy in a church community?
options: God will arise and set the oppressed in safety
The oppressed must fend for themselves
God ignores oppression within the community
Only human leaders can protect the needy
questions.correctAnswer: God will arise and set the oppressed in safety
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:5 assures believers that God will act on behalf of the oppressed and needy, encouraging trust and advocacy within the church.

questions.question: According to Psalms 12, what attitude do some have toward their speech and authority over their lips?
options: They claim their lips are their own and question who is lord over them
They submit fully to God's control over their speech
They respect their neighbors’ authority over their words
questions.correctAnswer: They claim their lips are their own and question who is lord over them
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:4 describes those who arrogantly claim control over their speech, challenging God's lordship, a warning against pride and self-rule.

questions.question: A Christian is struggling to forgive someone who has spoken proudly and deceitfully. What insight does Psalms 12 provide about dealing with such people?
options: God will judge proud and flattering speech, so trust His justice
Speak proudly back to them to defend yourself
questions.correctAnswer: God will judge proud and flattering speech, so trust His justice
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:3 and 12:2 reveal God’s judgment on proud and flattering lips, encouraging believers to leave justice in God’s hands rather than retaliate.

questions.question: How does Psalms 12 encourage believers to maintain spiritual discipline and trust in God’s word during difficult times?
options: By trusting the pure and preserved words of the LORD
By relying solely on human wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting the pure and preserved words of the LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:6-7 highlights that God’s words are pure and that He preserves them forever, encouraging believers to hold fast to Scripture in trials.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 12 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 12.

questions.question: In Psalms 12:1, what is the reason given for the plea for help to the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: The godly man ceaseth
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:1 states the plea is because 'the godly man ceaseth; for the faithful fail from among the children of men.'

questions.question: Which literary device is strongly present in Psalms 12:2 with the phrases 'flattering lips' and 'double heart'?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The verse uses parallelism by pairing 'flattering lips' and 'double heart' to emphasize deceit and duplicity in speech.

questions.question: What action does the LORD say He will take against 'all flattering lips' according to Psalms 12:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Cut them off
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:3 explicitly states, 'The LORD shall cut off all flattering lips, and the tongue that speaketh proud things.'

questions.question: In Psalms 12:4, what attitude do the deceitful speakers express regarding their own speech?
questions.correctAnswer: Our lips are our own
questions.explanation: The verse includes the phrase 'our lips are our own: who is lord over us?' showing their pride and independence in speech.

questions.question: How does Psalms 12:5 describe the LORD's response to the oppression of the poor?
options: He will arise and set them in safety
He will judge the oppressors later
questions.correctAnswer: He will arise and set them in safety
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'now will I arise, saith the LORD; I will set him in safety from him that puffeth at him,' indicating active intervention.

questions.question: The phrase 'pure words' in Psalms 12:6 is compared to what precious metal refined multiple times?
questions.correctAnswer: Silver refined seven times
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:6 states, 'The words of the LORD are pure words: as silver tried in a furnace of earth, purified seven times.'

questions.question: What promise does the psalmist make about the preservation of the LORD's words in Psalms 12:7?
options: They shall be preserved forever from this generation
They shall be hidden until the end times
They shall be forgotten by men
They shall be written on tablets of stone
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be preserved forever from this generation
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Thou shalt keep them, O LORD, thou shalt preserve them from this generation for ever,' emphasizing eternal preservation.

questions.question: In Psalms 12:8, who is described as walking on every side?
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'The wicked walk on every side, when the vilest men are exalted,' indicating pervasive evil.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 12 portrays the LORD as indifferent to the plight of the oppressed.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:5 shows the LORD will arise to protect the oppressed, indicating He is not indifferent.

questions.question: Which phrase in Psalms 12:2 best illustrates the concept of duplicity in speech?
options: With flattering lips and with a double heart
For the oppression of the poor
The words of the LORD are pure
questions.correctAnswer: With flattering lips and with a double heart
questions.explanation: This phrase directly describes deceitful and double-minded speech.

questions.question: How does Psalms 12:6's metaphor for the LORD's words relate to ancient Near Eastern cultural practices?
options: Refining silver in a furnace was a common metallurgical process symbolizing purity
Building temples was the main metaphor for purity
Harvesting grain was used to illustrate purity
Casting idols was a metaphor for refining
questions.correctAnswer: Refining silver in a furnace was a common metallurgical process symbolizing purity
questions.explanation: The analogy to silver purified seven times relates to ancient practices of refining metals to denote the absolute purity of God's words.

questions.question: In the historical context of Psalms 12, what might the phrase 'our lips are our own: who is lord over us?' in verse 4 suggest about the societal attitudes of the time?
options: A rebellious assertion of autonomy against divine authority
A humble submission to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: A rebellious assertion of autonomy against divine authority
questions.explanation: The phrase reflects prideful defiance and rejection of God's lordship, typical of corrupt leaders or societies in ancient Near Eastern contexts.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage reflects the theme of pure and trustworthy words similar to Psalms 12:6?
options: John 17:17 - 'Sanctify them through thy truth: thy word is truth.'
Romans 8:28 - 'All things work together for good.'
questions.correctAnswer: John 17:17 - 'Sanctify them through thy truth: thy word is truth.'
questions.explanation: John 17:17 emphasizes the purity and truthfulness of God's word, paralleling Psalm 12:6's description of pure words.

questions.question: What typological foreshadowing can be seen in Psalms 12:5's description of the LORD arising to save the needy?
options: The coming of Christ as protector and savior of the oppressed
questions.correctAnswer: The coming of Christ as protector and savior of the oppressed
questions.explanation: The LORD rising to save the needy foreshadows Christ's mission to protect and redeem the vulnerable.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 12:7 declares that the LORD will preserve His words from this generation __________.
questions.correctAnswer: for ever
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'Thou shalt preserve them from this generation for ever,' emphasizing eternal preservation.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 12 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 12 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary complaint of the psalmist in Psalms 12:1 regarding the godly?
options: The godly man ceaseth and the faithful fail
The godly are oppressed by the wicked
The godly are exalted above others
The godly are lost in idolatry
questions.correctAnswer: The godly man ceaseth and the faithful fail
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:1 expresses the lament that the godly are disappearing and the faithful are failing among men, showing a crisis in human faithfulness. Similar themes appear in Isaiah 1:4, Jeremiah 5:1, Matthew 24:12, and 2 Timothy 3:1-5 where faithfulness is in decline.

questions.question: According to Psalms 12:2, how do people speak to one another?
options: With vanity, flattering lips, and a double heart
questions.correctAnswer: With vanity, flattering lips, and a double heart
questions.explanation: The psalmist describes people speaking vanity with flattering lips and a double heart, indicating deceit and hypocrisy. This is consistent with Proverbs 6:17, Jeremiah 9:4, Romans 1:29, and James 3:14-16, which condemn deceitful speech.

questions.question: What divine action does the LORD promise in Psalms 12:3?
options: To cut off all flattering lips and proud tongues
To bless the humble and meek
To deliver the oppressed from enemies
To increase the wisdom of the faithful
questions.correctAnswer: To cut off all flattering lips and proud tongues
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:3 declares that God will cut off flattering lips and proud tongues, indicating divine judgment against deceitful and arrogant speech. This is echoed in Psalm 64:3-4, Proverbs 16:5, Isaiah 10:33, and Jude 1:16.

questions.question: In Psalms 12:4, what attitude do the wicked express about their speech and authority?
options: They claim their tongues will prevail and question who is lord over them
They confess their sins and seek forgiveness
They praise the LORD for His justice
They acknowledge the authority of God over their speech
questions.correctAnswer: They claim their tongues will prevail and question who is lord over them
questions.explanation: The wicked boast that their tongues will prevail and assert autonomy by questioning who has lordship over them, reflecting rebellion against God’s authority. Similar attitudes are found in Psalm 73:8, Jeremiah 5:31, Romans 1:30, and 2 Timothy 3:2.

questions.question: What does the LORD state He will do for the oppressed and needy in Psalms 12:5?
options: Arise and set them in safety from their oppressors
questions.correctAnswer: Arise and set them in safety from their oppressors
questions.explanation: God promises to rise up and protect the poor and needy from those who oppress them, demonstrating His justice and care. This theme is consistent with Exodus 22:22-24, Psalm 9:9, Isaiah 1:17, and Luke 4:18.

questions.question: How does Psalms 12:6 describe the words of the LORD?
options: Pure words, like silver refined seven times
questions.correctAnswer: Pure words, like silver refined seven times
questions.explanation: The psalmist affirms the purity of God’s words, likening them to silver purified seven times, highlighting divine perfection and trustworthiness. This aligns with Proverbs 30:5, Psalm 119:140, Isaiah 40:8, and John 17:17.

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask God to do with His words in Psalms 12:7?
options: To keep and preserve them forever from this generation
To forget them and move on
To change them according to circumstances
To give them only to the priests
questions.correctAnswer: To keep and preserve them forever from this generation
questions.explanation: Psalms 12:7 requests God to preserve His words eternally and protect them from corruption by the current generation, emphasizing the eternal nature of divine truth. Similar appeals appear in Psalm 119:152, Isaiah 40:8, Matthew 5:18, and 1 Peter 1:25.

questions.question: According to Psalms 12:8, what is the condition of the wicked and the vilest men?
options: The wicked walk on every side and the vilest men are exalted
The wicked are punished and the vilest men are humbled
The wicked repent and the vilest men are converted
The wicked are hidden and the vilest men are despised
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked walk on every side and the vilest men are exalted
questions.explanation: The psalm describes a world where wickedness is widespread and the most vile are elevated, reflecting a moral inversion. This is comparable to Proverbs 28:12, Ecclesiastes 8:14, Jeremiah 5:31, and 2 Timothy 3:13.

questions.question: What theological theme is emphasized by God's promise to 'arise' for the oppressed in Psalms 12:5?
options: God’s attribute of justice and protection for the vulnerable
God’s attribute of wrath without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: God’s attribute of justice and protection for the vulnerable
questions.explanation: God’s rising to protect the oppressed emphasizes His justice and care for the vulnerable, consistent with Exodus 34:7, Psalm 103:6, Isaiah 61:1-2, and Luke 1:50.

questions.question: How does Psalms 12:6 reflect the doctrine of the inerrancy and purity of Scripture?
options: By describing God's words as pure and refined like silver
By stating that God's words are sometimes mistaken
By emphasizing human interpretation over divine words
By suggesting God's words are adaptable to error
questions.correctAnswer: By describing God's words as pure and refined like silver
questions.explanation: The metaphor of words purified seven times highlights perfection and purity, affirming Scripture's inerrancy. This is supported by Psalm 19:7, Proverbs 30:5, John 10:35, and 2 Timothy 3:16.

questions.question: Which Christological theme can be inferred from God's promise to 'preserve the faithful' in Psalms 12:7?
options: The sustaining and preserving work of Christ as the Good Shepherd
Christ's role as a warrior defeating enemies
Christ's silence in the face of evil
questions.correctAnswer: The sustaining and preserving work of Christ as the Good Shepherd
questions.explanation: God preserving His people aligns with Christ's role as shepherd who guards and sustains the faithful (John 10:28-29, Hebrews 7:25, 1 Peter 2:25, and Revelation 7:17).

questions.question: What apologetic response does Psalms 12:3 provide regarding the prevalence of deceitful speech?
options: God will ultimately judge and remove deceitful tongues
Deceitful speech is acceptable in society
Lying is a sign of strength
questions.correctAnswer: God will ultimately judge and remove deceitful tongues
questions.explanation: The promise that God will cut off flattering lips reassures believers that God judges falsehood, answering skepticism about divine justice. This is consistent with Psalm 34:16, Proverbs 19:5, Isaiah 59:15-16, and Romans 12:19.

questions.question: How does Psalms 12:4 depict human rebellion against God’s sovereignty?
options: By claiming autonomy over speech and denying any lord over them
By confessing their sins and repenting
questions.correctAnswer: By claiming autonomy over speech and denying any lord over them
questions.explanation: The verse shows humans arrogantly asserting independence over their speech and denying God's lordship, reflecting sinfulness in human pride (Romans 1:25, Psalm 2:1-3, Isaiah 14:13-14, and James 4:6).

questions.question: What eschatological hope is implied in Psalms 12:7’s promise of preservation 'forever'?
options: The eternal preservation of God’s truth beyond this age
The temporary nature of God's promises
The destruction of all Scripture after this generation
The end of God's covenant with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The eternal preservation of God’s truth beyond this age
questions.explanation: The pledge to preserve God's words forever points to an eternal, eschatological hope for divine truth, consistent with Isaiah 40:8, Matthew 24:35, 1 Peter 1:23-25, and Revelation 21:5.

questions.question: What does the prevalence of wickedness in Psalms 12:8 suggest about the human condition?
options: That sin and rebellion have spread broadly in society
That only a few are wicked
questions.correctAnswer: That sin and rebellion have spread broadly in society
questions.explanation: The widespread presence of wickedness and exaltation of vile men reveals the pervasive corruption of humanity, as also shown in Genesis 6:5, Romans 3:10-12, Ecclesiastes 7:20, and Jeremiah 17:9.
